By JACK VITEK
The Johns Hopkins Poetry Festival, consisting of six
poetry readings and four lectures, will bring together eight
of America's well known poets over a five day period,
November 5 to 11, at Shriver Hall.
According to Mr. Elliott Coleman, co-director of the
Committee, the Festival "will bring together perhaps the
greatest concentration of poetic talent ever assembled at

one time in America for the express purpose of reading
and discussing poetry."

ROBERT FROST

Board Acknowledges
Detrimental Rushing
But Cannot Act
Interfraternity Board President Steve Broening and several
members of the IFB have agreed
with Phi Gamma Delta President
Mickey Webster that dirty rushing in the form of detrimental
remarks occurred during the rush
season, but they confess that they
know no way to prevent it.
Broening said at Friday's IFB
m ee tin g, "The Gentleman's
Agreement was not abided by in
rushing this year." But he confessed that although there is a
rule against detrimental talk
out one fraternity and its
members by. another to freshmen, the provision is "hard to
enforce and prove."
"I know of no way of stopping
people from saying bad things
about other fraternities other
than through the realization of
a superior ethic," he said.
Webster Lashes Out
Webster castigated fraternity
rushing methods in a ten-minute
accusation. "Supposedly, Johns
Hopkins is a university for gentlemen, but during rushing, it
takes on a different character,"
he said.
Noting that "things have occurred during rushing which are
not only ungentlemanly but
against ethics," Webster revealed
strong emotions of disgust as he
said, "I get a little tired when
rushing of hearing ten or twelve
comments about my fraternity
and my brothers—all of which
are detrimental."
"I don't think this is right,"
he said. "As a gentleman, it fills
me with disgust for other fraternity men and for the rushing setup as a whole."
Free Choice
Webster said. that he and his
fraternity "rush like gentlemen"
and believe that a freshman
should be free to make his own
choice of a fraternity without
being pressured and confused by
the dirty rushing tactics, of,other
fraternity men. "It is the freshman's life and his decision," he
argued. "If the freshman is confused (by deliberate slander during rushing) he is likely to make
a decision which will make him
(Continued on Page 6).

MARK VAN DOREN -

Pajama Ball 'Set
For Gymnasium
Tomorrow Nile
The Booster Club will launch
the first event of its 1958-59 social season tomorrow night with
the "Pajama Ball", from 9 to 1
in the gymnasium.
All Hopkins men and their
dates attending the affair will
be required to be attired in
pajamas or night clothes of some
sort, ccording to Cloyd Kerchner, vice-president of the Boosters. He added, "We expect this
dance to be a very successful
one."
Mal Levine and Lester Gurwitt,
co-chairmen of the affair, have
arranged to have round tables
for the cabaret style dance, instead of the conventional set-up
of rows of rectangular tables.
The decorations will follow "an
imaginative scheme in keeping
with the dance", according to
Levine and Gurwitt.
Kerchner also stated, "The
Booster Club would appreciate
the cooperation of the students
in that during and after the
dance they do not destroy or
damage school property in any
way while having a good time."
Tickets for the dance will be
$2.25 in advance or $2.50 at the
door.
Iry Seculow, chairman of the
Gentleman's Code Committee of
the Student Council, issued the
following statement concerning
the conduct of Hopkins students
attending this dance.
"The Gentleman's Code Committee of the Student Council
would like to take this opportunity, prior to the Pajama Ball,
(Continued on Page 3)

Four lectures, "The Poetry of
Edwin Muir"—R. P. Blackmur,
"Poetic Styles, Old and New"—
Yvor Winters, "The Poetry of
Dame Edith Sitwell"—Marianne
Moore, and "The Poetry of Thomas Hardy"—Mark Van Doren,
are scheduled at 4:30 on Wednesday, November 5; Friday, November 7, Monday, November 10:
and Tuesday, November 11; in
that order.
Two-Hour Sessions
During the intervening weekend, three separate two-hour
sessions are planned •during
which poets Archibald MacLeish,
Yvor Winters, Marianne Moore,
John Crowe Ransom, E. E. Cummings and Robert Frost will read
their own works. These readings
will be recorded by the Library
of Congress and also by the Voice
of America, which has asked to
broadcast the readings to Europe.
In addition, Time, Incorporated
will be represented by reporters
and photographers from Life,
The Committee is saddened
by the news that William Carlos
Williams, who was originally
scheduled to participate in the
Festival, has suffered a stroke.
However, they are happy to report that he is recovering and
that John Crowe Ransom has
consented to take his place in
the program.
Turnbull Lectures
The Festival is the result of
a collaboration between the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Lecture
Committee, headed by Dr. Don
Cameron Allen, and the Writing
Seminars, directed by Mr. Elliot
Coleman.
The poetry readings will be
sponsored by the Writing Seminars with the assistance of a
grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The lectures will constitute the Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial Lectures, given
every two years at Hopkins since
1889.
There will be no admission
charge to the session and the
public is invited to attend.
Critical Blackmur
R. P. Blackmur, a scholar without formal university training,
now a professor of English at
Princeton, is the author of four
well known volumes of critical
essays and three collections of
poetry. As a frequent lecturer,
Professor Blackmur has won wide
acclaim for his critical studies.
The London Times described
his method as follows: "So
thorough is examination, so high
the standards he sets, and so
fascinating the mind brought to
bear on the work that (his)
judgment • is always impressive .. ."

school teacher, Dr. Yvor Winters

Tonkin explained that his plan

unfavorable criticism." He said

the right direction."
"I hope that the outcome of
these proposals will bring a continuing improvement in dormitory student government," Tonkin commented.
When asked his opinion on the
proposed revisions in electoral
Procedure, Dr. Morrill said: "I
don't care how the DSRC officers are elected, provided that
We can be assured
that thought
Will be given to choosing good
Men. If the students can do this

that Baker
He explained
House members have purchased
a second-hand television set.
"They have a lock on their lounge
door so that only members of the
house, with room keys that fit
the lounge lock, can enter the
lounge. This way they have full
responsibiilty for the safety of
the TV set," Tonkin said, adding that "the administration is
matching the students' effort by
purchasing drapes for the Baker
House Lounge."
Showing a marked enthusiasm
over "the apparent reinterest of
the students in their own welfare," Tonkin stated: "If the destruction goes down, the prospect for continued cooperation
in student efforts is bright."

of players." They have been in

Gray Globs
Stepping out of the editorial bull ring, we naively
venture into an area which produces much waste—the
game of politics. In doing this, we can not, with impunity,
assure our readers, as do the large dailies, that our choices
are "gray globs" (to borrow a phrase from John F. Lewis
Our only editorial feeling toward the forthcoming
election is one of frustrated disinterest. The intelligent
voter simply has no choice. All of the Maryland candidates
are "gray globes" (to borrow a phrase form John F. Lewis
of WBAL). There are no issues, no personalities, no
debates. All seem content to depend on machines and
coattails rather than ideas and performance for votes. In
short, Marylanders are asked to vote for a lesser of evils

In all my years of observing coed fashions—and I have been
arrested many times—I have never seen such verve, such dash,
such Je ne sais quoi as can be found in this _year's styles!
I am particularly enchanted by the new "baby waist" dresses
Which so many of you girls are favoring this season. How
demure you all look in your "baby waists"! How sweet! How
innocent! How colorful when your housemother lifts you up
and burps you after dinner!
Another trend that leaves me limp with rapture is the oversized handbag. Goodbye to dinky little purses that hold nothing
at all! Hurrah for today's sensibly sized bag with plenty of
room for your makeup, your pens and pencils, your shelter
half, your Slinky toy, your MG,and your Marlboros.
Did I say Marlboros? Certainly I said Marlboros. What girl
can consider herself in the van, in the swim, and in the know,
if she doesn't smoke Marlboros? What man, for that matter.
Do you want a filter that is truly new, genuinely advanced,
but at the same time, does not rob you of the full flavor of
first-rate tobacco? Then get Marlboro. Also get matches because
the pleasure you derive from a Marlboro is necessarily limited
if unlit.
To return to coed fashions, let us now discuss footwear. The
Popular flat shoe was introduced several .years ago when it
became obvious that girls were growing taller than boys. For
a while the flat shoes kept the sexes in a state of uneasy balance,
but today they will no longer serve. Now, even in flats, girls
are -Awing over their dates, for the feminine growth .rate has
Continued to rise with disturbing speed. In fact, it is now
thought possible that we will see fifteen-foot girls in our lifetime.
But science is 'Working on the problem, and • I feel sure
American know-how will find an answer. Meanwhile, a tonTH.gary measure is available—the reverse wedgie.
The reverse wedgie is simply a wedgie turned around.. This
tilts a girl backward at a 45 degree angle and cuts as much as
three feet off her height. It is, of course, impossible to walk in
this position unless you have support, so your date will have to
k(Tel") his arm around your waist at all times. This will tire him
out in fairly short order; therefore you must constantly give
_nuo encouragement. Keep looking up at him and batting your
lashes and repeating in awed tones, "How strong you are,
bliorty

To The Editors:
I am very sorry that you found
it necessary to print a letter
which I intended to be a personal
and private one containing offhand opinions which I am in
no position to document, and
haphazardly excerpted, on the
editorial page of the News-Letter. In the first place, I do not
think that the opinions of an
alumnus, out of touch with the
Homewood situation, belong in
the paper, which is, after all, an
undergraduate publication. But
if they did, surely it would be
wiser to ask for a balanced estimate, preferably from more than

one judge, than to bolster whatever drift your editorial thinking may have by publishing a
private opinion .which has fallen
into your hands. Your lengthy
but circuitous identification of
me has put all the Hopkins students here under the incubus of
appearing to have yielded to that
peculiar snobbery which is one
of the several drawbacks of Harvard not mentioned in my letter.
This may give some pause to the
people who were kind enough to
give us recommendations to come
here.
Any balancing of Harvard visa-vis Hopkins would have to take

EVERLASTING IMPRESSIONS
CAN BE MADE WITH

.AfilARM

into account, not only the fact
that the best school for an individual is a highly subjective
matter, but also the slight matter of about $1 billion difference in endowment, for example.
Money is not everything; my experience at Hopkins is very important to me and I am by no
means sure it could have been.
matched here. What Johns Hopkins charges for an education
was my business when I sat in
the chair you now occupy; I do
not think it is my place to continue sniping at the News-Letter's readers from outside. I have
my views, for example, completely opposite to yours on the matter of acceptance of government
assistance, but I have not sought
to inflict them on your readers.
I now begin to understand the
anguish of others whose views
have turned up in garbled or unforeseen form. This letter, unlike my previous one, I intend for
publication, in order that at least
my fellow alumni here may be
relieved of responsibility.
Yours very truly,
John Rothney

By JACK VITEK
The Johns Hopkins Poetry Festival, consisting of six
poetry readings and four lectures, will bring together eight
of America's well known poets over a five day period,
November 5 to 11, at Shriver Hall.
According to Mr. Elliott Coleman, co-director of the
Committee, the Festival "will bring together perhaps the
greatest concentration of poetic talent ever assembled at

one time in America for the express purpose of reading
and discussing poetry."

ROBERT FROST

Board Acknowledges
Detrimental Rushing
But Cannot Act
Interfraternity Board President Steve Broening and several
members of the IFB have agreed
with Phi Gamma Delta President
Mickey Webster that dirty rushing in the form of detrimental
remarks occurred during the rush
season, but they confess that they
know no way to prevent it.
Broening said at Friday's IFB
m ee tin g, "The Gentleman's
Agreement was not abided by in
rushing this year." But he confessed that although there is a
rule against detrimental talk
out one fraternity and its
members by. another to freshmen, the provision is "hard to
enforce and prove."
"I know of no way of stopping
people from saying bad things
about other fraternities other
than through the realization of
a superior ethic," he said.
Webster Lashes Out
Webster castigated fraternity
rushing methods in a ten-minute
accusation. "Supposedly, Johns
Hopkins is a university for gentlemen, but during rushing, it
takes on a different character,"
he said.
Noting that "things have occurred during rushing which are
not only ungentlemanly but
against ethics," Webster revealed
strong emotions of disgust as he
said, "I get a little tired when
rushing of hearing ten or twelve
comments about my fraternity
and my brothers—all of which
are detrimental."
"I don't think this is right,"
he said. "As a gentleman, it fills
me with disgust for other fraternity men and for the rushing setup as a whole."
Free Choice
Webster said. that he and his
fraternity "rush like gentlemen"
and believe that a freshman
should be free to make his own
choice of a fraternity without
being pressured and confused by
the dirty rushing tactics, of,other
fraternity men. "It is the freshman's life and his decision," he
argued. "If the freshman is confused (by deliberate slander during rushing) he is likely to make
a decision which will make him
(Continued on Page 6).

MARK VAN DOREN -

Pajama Ball 'Set
For Gymnasium
Tomorrow Nile
The Booster Club will launch
the first event of its 1958-59 social season tomorrow night with
the "Pajama Ball", from 9 to 1
in the gymnasium.
All Hopkins men and their
dates attending the affair will
be required to be attired in
pajamas or night clothes of some
sort, ccording to Cloyd Kerchner, vice-president of the Boosters. He added, "We expect this
dance to be a very successful
one."
Mal Levine and Lester Gurwitt,
co-chairmen of the affair, have
arranged to have round tables
for the cabaret style dance, instead of the conventional set-up
of rows of rectangular tables.
The decorations will follow "an
imaginative scheme in keeping
with the dance", according to
Levine and Gurwitt.
Kerchner also stated, "The
Booster Club would appreciate
the cooperation of the students
in that during and after the
dance they do not destroy or
damage school property in any
way while having a good time."
Tickets for the dance will be
$2.25 in advance or $2.50 at the
door.
Iry Seculow, chairman of the
Gentleman's Code Committee of
the Student Council, issued the
following statement concerning
the conduct of Hopkins students
attending this dance.
"The Gentleman's Code Committee of the Student Council
would like to take this opportunity, prior to the Pajama Ball,

Four lectures, "The Poetry of
Edwin Muir"—R. P. Blackmur,
"Poetic Styles, Old and New"—
Yvor Winters, "The Poetry of
Dame Edith Sitwell"—Marianne
Moore, and "The Poetry of Thomas Hardy"—Mark Van Doren,
are scheduled at 4:30 on Wednesday, November 5; Friday, November 7, Monday, November 10:
and Tuesday, November 11; in
that order.
Two-Hour Sessions
During the intervening weekend, three separate two-hour
sessions are planned •during
which poets Archibald MacLeish,
Yvor Winters, Marianne Moore,
John Crowe Ransom, E. E. Cummings and Robert Frost will read
their own works. These readings
will be recorded by the Library
of Congress and also by the Voice
of America, which has asked to
broadcast the readings to Europe.
In addition, Time, Incorporated
will be represented by reporters
and photographers from Life,
The Committee is saddened
by the news that William Carlos
Williams, who was originally
scheduled to participate in the
Festival, has suffered a stroke.
However, they are happy to report that he is recovering and
that John Crowe Ransom has
consented to take his place in
the program.
Turnbull Lectures
The Festival is the result of
a collaboration between the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Lecture
Committee, headed by Dr. Don
Cameron Allen, and the Writing
Seminars, directed by Mr. Elliot
Coleman.
The poetry readings will be
sponsored by the Writing Seminars with the assistance of a
grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The lectures will constitute the Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial Lectures, given
every two years at Hopkins since
1889.
There will be no admission
charge to the session and the
public is invited to attend.
Critical Blackmur
R. P. Blackmur, a scholar without formal university training,
now a professor of English at
Princeton, is the author of four
well known volumes of critical
essays and three collections of
poetry. As a frequent lecturer,
Professor Blackmur has won wide
acclaim for his critical studies.
The London Times described
his method as follows: "So
thorough is examination, so high
the standards he sets, and so
fascinating the mind brought to
bear on the work that (his)
judgment • is always impressive .. ."

Gray Globs
Stepping out of the editorial bull ring, we naively
venture into an area which produces much waste—the
game of politics. In doing this, we can not, with impunity,
assure our readers, as do the large dailies, that our choices
are "gray globs" (to borrow a phrase from John F. Lewis
Our only editorial feeling toward the forthcoming
election is one of frustrated disinterest. The intelligent
voter simply has no choice. All of the Maryland candidates

debates. All seem content to depend on machines and
coattails rather than ideas and performance for votes. In
short, Marylanders are asked to vote for a lesser of evils

In all my years of observing coed fashions—and I have been
arrested many times—I have never seen such verve, such dash,
such Je ne sais quoi as can be found in this _year's styles!
I am particularly enchanted by the new "baby waist" dresses
Which so many of you girls are favoring this season. How
demure you all look in your "baby waists"! How sweet! How
innocent! How colorful when your housemother lifts you up
and burps you after dinner!
Another trend that leaves me limp with rapture is the oversized handbag. Goodbye to dinky little purses that hold nothing
at all! Hurrah for today's sensibly sized bag with plenty of
room for your makeup, your pens and pencils, your shelter
half, your Slinky toy, your MG,and your Marlboros.
Did I say Marlboros? Certainly I said Marlboros. What girl
can consider herself in the van, in the swim, and in the know,
if she doesn't smoke Marlboros? What man, for that matter.
Do you want a filter that is truly new, genuinely advanced,
but at the same time, does not rob you of the full flavor of
first-rate tobacco? Then get Marlboro. Also get matches because
the pleasure you derive from a Marlboro is necessarily limited
if unlit.
To return to coed fashions, let us now discuss footwear. The
Popular flat shoe was introduced several .years ago when it
became obvious that girls were growing taller than boys. For
a while the flat shoes kept the sexes in a state of uneasy balance,
but today they will no longer serve. Now, even in flats, girls
are -Awing over their dates, for the feminine growth .rate has
Continued to rise with disturbing speed. In fact, it is now
thought possible that we will see fifteen-foot girls in our lifetime.
But science is 'Working on the problem, and • I feel sure
American know-how will find an answer. Meanwhile, a tonTH.gary measure is available—the reverse wedgie.
The reverse wedgie is simply a wedgie turned around.. This
tilts a girl backward at a 45 degree angle and cuts as much as
three feet off her height. It is, of course, impossible to walk in
this position unless you have support, so your date will have to
k(Tel") his arm around your waist at all times. This will tire him
out in fairly short order; therefore you must constantly give
_nuo encouragement. Keep looking up at him and batting your
lashes and repeating in awed tones, "How strong you are,
bliorty

if they did, surely it would be
wiser to ask for a balanced estimate, preferably from more than

one judge, than to bolster whatever drift your editorial thinking may have by publishing a
private opinion .which has fallen
into your hands. Your lengthy
but circuitous identification of
me has put all the Hopkins students here under the incubus of
appearing to have yielded to that
peculiar snobbery which is one
of the several drawbacks of Harvard not mentioned in my letter.
This may give some pause to the
people who were kind enough to
give us recommendations to come
here.
Any balancing of Harvard visa-vis Hopkins would have to take

EVERLASTING IMPRESSIONS
CAN BE MADE WITH

.AfilARM

into account, not only the fact
that the best school for an individual is a highly subjective
matter, but also the slight matter of about $1 billion difference in endowment, for example.
Money is not everything; my experience at Hopkins is very important to me and I am by no
means sure it could have been.
matched here. What Johns Hopkins charges for an education
was my business when I sat in
the chair you now occupy; I do
not think it is my place to continue sniping at the News-Letter's readers from outside. I have
my views, for example, completely opposite to yours on the matter of acceptance of government
assistance, but I have not sought
to inflict them on your readers.
I now begin to understand the
anguish of others whose views
have turned up in garbled or unforeseen form. This letter, unlike my previous one, I intend for
publication, in order that at least
my fellow alumni here may be
relieved of responsibility.
Yours very truly,
John Rothney
